message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tumor is small and the pathological specimen has certain characteristics that can be treated with hormone therapy. Lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy followed by radiation and hormone therapy is the most appropriate next step. Nipple-sparing mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection would be an option in certain cases but is not necessary for this patient. Radical mastectomy is not necessary for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diagnosis is a low-grade infiltrating ductal carcinoma positive for estrogen receptors and negative for progesterone and HER2 receptors. Lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by radiation and hormone therapy, is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient. Nipple-sparing mastectomy and radical mastectomy are not necessary as the tumor is small and localized. Hormone therapy is necessary as the tumor is estrogen receptor positive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The size of the mass is small (less than 2 cm) and there is no distant metastatic disease, which suggests stage I breast cancer. Lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by radiation and hormone therapy, is the standard of care for stage I breast cancer, as it has been found to be just as effective as mastectomy with lower morbidity rates. The fact that the tumor is positive for estrogen receptors suggests that hormone therapy should also be administered. Nipple-sparing mastectomy is not necessary in this situation, as the tumor is located away from the nipple-areolar complex and there are no changes in the skin or nipple. Radical mastectomy is too aggressive for stage I breast cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s low-grade infiltrating ductal carcinoma, positive estrogen receptors, and negative progesterone and HER2 receptors suggest a favorable prognosis. Lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by radiation and hormone therapy, is the most appropriate next step in management. Nipple-sparing mastectomy or radical mastectomy are more aggressive than necessary for this patient, and lumpectomy alone may not be sufficient for a low-grade infiltrating carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diagnosis is infiltrating ductal carcinoma, which is the most common type of breast cancer. The tumor is small, localized, and has not spread to distant sites, so the most appropriate next step would be a lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by radiation and hormone therapy. Nipple-sparing mastectomy or radical mastectomy are more extensive surgeries that may not be necessary for this type of tumor. Hormone therapy is also appropriate since the tumor is positive for estrogen receptors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. An invasive ductal carcinoma and positive estrogen receptor suggest hormone therapy is a suitable treatment option. The tumor is small and located in the left breast, and there is no evidence of metastasis, indicating a good prognosis. A lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy followed by radiation and hormone therapy is the most appropriate next step in management. Nipple-sparing mastectomy and radical mastectomy are more invasive and not necessary for this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The size and location of the tumor, as well as the absence of distant metastatic disease, suggest a lumpectomy is appropriate. The tumor is positive for estrogen receptors, which suggests it will respond to hormone therapy. Sentinel lymph node biopsy is appropriate to assess for spread to axillary lymph nodes. Radiation therapy is also appropriate to decrease the risk of local recurrence. Therefore, the most appropriate next step would be a lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by radiation and hormone therapy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has early-stage breast cancer with moderate-sized, mobile tumor and no distant metastasis. Lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy followed by radiation and hormone therapy is the appropriate treatment plan. Nipple-sparing mastectomy and radical mastectomy are more aggressive options and not necessary in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low-grade infiltrating ductal carcinoma, positive estrogen receptors and negative progesterone and HER2 receptors suggest a lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by radiation and hormone therapy. Nipple-sparing mastectomy may not be necessary and over-treatment may cause unnecessary side effects. Radical mastectomy is not necessary due to the absence of distant metastatic disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a small, low-grade infiltrating ductal carcinoma that is positive for estrogen receptors and negative for progesterone and HER2 receptors. This suggests a good prognosis and the most appropriate management is a lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by radiation and hormone therapy. Nipple-sparing mastectomy may not be necessary and radical mastectomy is not as common anymore.
